node.text:
Educator Shana White discusses how she uses art to bring every student's identity into the classroom. "Identity portraits are a project that allows kids to express their own identities. It's a really big growth point for a lot of kids that they are able to be comfortable with who they are and recognize and respect the identity markers of anybody." 🖌

#Diversity #CulturallyResponsiveTeaching #SEL #SocialEmotionalLearning #Arts #ArtEducation

node.title: Exploring Perceptions About Identity Through Self-Portraits

node.title: How to Foster Metacognitive Skills for Independent Learning

node.text:
It’s time to rethink our definition of what a “good school” is, researchers assert in a new study.⁣
⁣
That’s because the usual signals we rely on to gauge the quality of a school—namely, high test scores—are often incomplete and misleading, the researchers found. ⁣
⁣
The study looked at over 150,000 ninth-grade students who attended Chicago public schools and concluded that schools that emphasize the social and emotional dimensions of learning—relationship-building, a sense of belonging, and resilience, for example—improve high school graduation and college matriculation rates for both high- and low-income students, beating out schools that improve test scores.⁣
⁣
In an interview with Edutopia, C. Kirabo Jackson, the lead researcher and a professor of education and social policy at Northwestern University, explained that schools with robust impacts on student well-being aren’t getting the recognition they deserve. Students in these schools not only have a more positive experience, but are also more likely to graduate and attend college, especially “vulnerable student populations who don’t tend to do very well in the education system,” Jackson said.⁣
⁣
The findings emphasize the need to take a multi-pronged approach to student well-being, and are a reminder that schools—and teachers—can influence students in ways that are difficult to measure, and may only materialize well into the future.⁣

#EducationResearch #SEL #SocialEmotionalLearning #SocialEmotionalDevelopment #StudentWellBeing #TeachersOfInstagram

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Edutopia on July 12, 2021. May be an image of text that says '@e IF-FEEE ASSESSMENT 5 Ways to Help Students Focus Learning Rather Than Grades on'.

node.text:
Like many math teachers, Crystal Frommert was used to questions like “What can I do to get my average up to an A?” and “How many points off if I forgot units?”⁣
⁣
She wished the middle and high school students she taught over the years were focused on learning, but rather than blame them, she reflected on how she had “contributed to the grade-obsessed culture” by praising students “based on their grades rather than their effort and improvement.”⁣
⁣
So she and a group of teachers at her school shared strategies and resources to de-emphasize grades in their classes—“even though we still had to give them.”⁣
⁣
1. Adjust your language: Rather than using threatening statements about grades, Frommert shifted to encouragement, such as, “You did really well with simplifying radicals. I’m looking forward to seeing how you apply that skill to the Pythagorean theorem.”⁣
⁣
She also shifted her language with parents: “I would email or call with information about the concepts or skills their child was demonstrating rather than emphasizing grades,” she writes.⁣
⁣
2. Delay the grade: Frommert began to grade tests with the usual marks—but did not write any point deductions or a grade on the test itself. Afterward, she asked students to reflect and make corrections that they then discussed with her.⁣
⁣
3. Lower the stakes: Frommert stopped recording completion grades for homework and started emphasizing it as a “chance to practice and explore.” She also dropped each student’s lowest quiz grade each term.⁣
⁣
4. Provide retakes: Frommert’s high school math department had a policy of “offering a retake test per term to replace the lowest test grade,” she writes.⁣
⁣
5. Allow self-grading: Research shows that giving grades can have detrimental effects. One way teachers can counter that is through “giving students more ownership of their assessment” by having them complete their own rubric, which can lead to productive conversations with students and boost their metacognitive skills.⁣
⁣
Link in bio.⁣

#StudentAssessment #Homework #MiddleSchoolTeacher #HighSchoolTeacher

node.text:
Silent reading is important, but before sending kids off with a book, set them up for success by scaffolding the activity. Consider pre-teaching vocabulary, providing a plot overview, and maybe introducing a K-W-L activity in which students write about what they already (K)now, add questions about (W)hat they’d like to know, and then summarize what they (L)earned.

“Many of us, myself included, are guilty of sending students all alone down the bumpy, muddy path known as Challenging Text—a road booby-trapped with difficult vocabulary,” writes Rebecca Alber, an instructor at UCLA’s Graduate School of Education. “We send them ill-prepared and then are often shocked when they lose interest, create a ruckus, or fall asleep.” When pre-teaching vocabulary, “introduce the words to kids in photos or in context with things they know and are interested in,” Alber says. “Give time for small-group and whole-class discussion of the words.”

#TeacherTip #ScaffoldingStrategy #SilentReading #TeacherTips

node.text:
Under bright lights and swirling rainbow-colored confetti, 14-year-old Zaila Avant-garde became the first Black American to win the @scrippsnationalspellingbee yesterday, winning on the word murraya—a genus of tropical Asiatic and Australian trees. 

“Does this word contain the English name ‘Murray,’ which can be the name of a comedian or just an English name in general?” asked Avant-garde, a rising ninth grader and native of Harvey, Louisiana, before answering correctly.

This year, 209 competitors from the United States and abroad were up against a new format of the bee that included vocabulary questions—Avant-garde’s specialty. She says she spent two years preparing for the competition, succeeding in the nine final rounds to take home the win. In addition to the trophy, Avant-garde—who also holds three @guinnessworldrecords titles for her basketball skills—received a $50,000 cash prize. 

“She really just had a much different approach than any speller I’ve ever seen,” said Cole Shafer-Ray, Avant-garde’s private coach and 2015 Scripps bee runner-up.

Avant-garde’s victory marks a historic turning point. Until the passage of the Civil Rights Act of 1964, Black children were often barred from participating in spelling bees. In the almost 100 years of the Scripps competition, Jody-Anne Maxwell—who represented Jamaica in 1998—has been the sole non-American Black champion. On national television, Avant-garde said she hopes to see many more African Americans excelling in spelling—and winning competitions. 

As for her next steps, Avant-garde has her sights set on playing professional basketball, attending Harvard University, and maybe even working for NASA. 

“I’m gonna have lots of fun. That’s about the broadest description I can give you,” said Avant-garde, smiling, of her plans to celebrate.

Photo Credit: Scripps National Spelling Bee

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Edutopia on July 06, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'Taking Bold Action for Environmental Change IPSWICH MIDDLE SCHOOL lpswich, Massachusetts @edutopia'.

node.text:
When piping plovers flock to the popular Crane Beach in Ipswich each spring, they have their own dedicated section of sand to use for nesting, thanks to students at Ipswich Middle School. 
 
Bringing awareness to the local environment is a guiding principle that drives environmental education at the school, says teacher Tina McMahon. Seventh graders start the year with a basic ecology background that allows them to dive into a water quality unit, where they measure the salinity, dissolved oxygen, and pH of the Ipswich River, which has made the endangered rivers list three times, including this year.
 
“It’s not only about helping students educate and make connections to other people; it’s about helping them understand their own environment and how they can add to the sustainability of where they live,” explained McMahon.
 
To learn about ways to conserve the natural habitat, students also take a two-day canoe trip to examine the health of the local soil, plants, animals, and macroinvertebrates.
 
But environmental education at Ipswich isn’t just a science-only undertaking. In an innovative project led by the math department, seventh graders created a functioning mini-golf course using plastic turf that can be reused year after year.
 
To design the layout, students investigated the principles of topography and used mathematical equations to calculate the dimensions for and the distance between the golf holes. In addition, they put up placards around the course with information about the harmful impact of pesticides on wetlands and ways to protect nearby native habitats.

#EnvironmentalEducation #InquiryBasedLearning #PlaceBasedLearning #MiddleSchoolTeacher #HighSchoolTeacher
